trans-unit.source: Move data between on-premises and cloud using Azure Data Factory
trans-unit.target: Move data between on-premises and cloud using Azure Data Factory

trans-unit.source: Learn about moving data between on-premises and cloud using Data Management Gateway and Azure Data Factory.
trans-unit.target: Learn about moving data between on-premises and cloud using Data Management Gateway and Azure Data Factory.

trans-unit.source: Move Data Between On-premises Sources and Cloud with Data Management Gateway
trans-unit.target: Move Data Between On-premises Sources and Cloud with Data Management Gateway

trans-unit.source: One of the challenges for modern data integration is to seamlessly move data to and from on-premises to cloud.
trans-unit.target: One of the challenges for modern data integration is to seamlessly move data to and from on-premises to cloud.

trans-unit.source: Data factory makes this integration seamless with data management gateway.
trans-unit.target: Data factory makes this integration seamless with data management gateway.

trans-unit.source: Data factory management gateway is an agent you can install on-premises to enable hybrid pipelines.
trans-unit.target: Data factory management gateway is an agent you can install on-premises to enable hybrid pipelines.

trans-unit.source: This article provides an overview of integrating on-premises data stores with cloud data stores and cloud processing using data factory.
trans-unit.target: This article provides an overview of integrating on-premises data stores with cloud data stores and cloud processing using data factory.

trans-unit.source: This article builds on the <link><linkText>Data Movement Activities</linkText><title></title></link> article and other data factory core concepts articles.
trans-unit.target: This article builds on the <link><linkText>Data Movement Activities</linkText><title></title></link> article and other data factory core concepts articles.

trans-unit.source: The following overview assumes you are familiar with data factory concepts like pipelines, activities, datasets and the copy activity.
trans-unit.target: The following overview assumes you are familiar with data factory concepts like pipelines, activities, datasets and the copy activity.

trans-unit.source: The data gateway provides the following capabilities:
trans-unit.target: The data gateway provides the following capabilities:

trans-unit.source: Model on-premises data sources and cloud data sources within the same data factory and move data.
trans-unit.target: Model on-premises data sources and cloud data sources within the same data factory and move data.

trans-unit.source: Have a single pane of glass for monitoring and management with visibility into gateway status with data factory cloud dashboard.
trans-unit.target: Have a single pane of glass for monitoring and management with visibility into gateway status with data factory cloud dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Manage access to on-premises data sources securely.
trans-unit.target: Manage access to on-premises data sources securely.

trans-unit.source: No changes required to corporate firewall.
trans-unit.target: No changes required to corporate firewall.

trans-unit.source: Gateway only makes outbound HTTP based connections to open internet.
trans-unit.target: Gateway only makes outbound HTTP based connections to open internet.

trans-unit.source: Encrypt credentials for your on-premises data stores with your certificate.
trans-unit.target: Encrypt credentials for your on-premises data stores with your certificate.

trans-unit.source: Move data efficiently – data is transferred in parallel, resilient to intermittent network issues with auto retry logic.
trans-unit.target: Move data efficiently – data is transferred in parallel, resilient to intermittent network issues with auto retry logic.

trans-unit.source: Considerations for using Data Management Gateway
trans-unit.target: Considerations for using Data Management Gateway

trans-unit.source: A single instance of Data Management Gateway can be used for multiple on-premises data sources, but note that a single gateway instance is tied to only one Azure data factory and cannot be shared with another data factory.
trans-unit.target: A single instance of Data Management Gateway can be used for multiple on-premises data sources, but note that a single gateway instance is tied to only one Azure data factory and cannot be shared with another data factory.

trans-unit.source: You can have only one instance of Data Management Gateway installed on a single machine.
trans-unit.target: You can have only one instance of Data Management Gateway installed on a single machine.

trans-unit.source: Suppose, you have two data factories that need to access on-premises data sources, you need to install gateways on two on-premises computers where each gateway tied to a separate data factory.
trans-unit.target: Suppose, you have two data factories that need to access on-premises data sources, you need to install gateways on two on-premises computers where each gateway tied to a separate data factory.

trans-unit.source: The gateway does not need to be on the same machine as the data source, but staying closer to the data source reduces the time for the gateway to connect to the data source.
trans-unit.target: The gateway does not need to be on the same machine as the data source, but staying closer to the data source reduces the time for the gateway to connect to the data source.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you install the gateway on a machine that is different from the one that hosts on-premises data source so that the gateway does not compete for resources with data source.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you install the gateway on a machine that is different from the one that hosts on-premises data source so that the gateway does not compete for resources with data source.

trans-unit.source: You can have multiple gateways on different machines connecting to the same on-premises data source.
trans-unit.target: You can have multiple gateways on different machines connecting to the same on-premises data source.

trans-unit.source: For example, you may have two gateways serving two data factories but the same on-premises data source is registered with both the data factories.
trans-unit.target: For example, you may have two gateways serving two data factories but the same on-premises data source is registered with both the data factories.

trans-unit.source: If you already have a gateway installed on your computer serving a Power BI scenario, please install a separate gateway for Azure Data Factory on another machine.
trans-unit.target: If you already have a gateway installed on your computer serving a Power BI scenario, please install a separate gateway for Azure Data Factory on another machine.

trans-unit.source: You must use the gateway even when you use ExpressRoute.
trans-unit.target: You must use the gateway even when you use ExpressRoute.

trans-unit.source: You should treat your data source as an on-premises data source (that is behind a firewall) even when you use ExpressRoute and use the gateway to establish connectivity between the service and the data source.
trans-unit.target: You should treat your data source as an on-premises data source (that is behind a firewall) even when you use ExpressRoute and use the gateway to establish connectivity between the service and the data source.

trans-unit.source: Gateway installation - prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Gateway installation - prerequisites

trans-unit.source: The supported Operating System versions are Windows 7, Windows 8/8.1, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012.
trans-unit.target: The supported Operating System versions are Windows 7, Windows 8/8.1, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012.

trans-unit.source: The recommended configuration for the gateway machine is at least 2 GHz, 4 cores, 8 GB RAM and 80 GB disk.
trans-unit.target: The recommended configuration for the gateway machine is at least 2 GHz, 4 cores, 8 GB RAM and 80 GB disk.

trans-unit.source: If the host machine hibernates, the gateway won’t be able to respond to data requests.
trans-unit.target: If the host machine hibernates, the gateway won’t be able to respond to data requests.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, configure an appropriate power plan on the computer before installing the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, configure an appropriate power plan on the computer before installing the gateway.

trans-unit.source: The gateway installation prompts a message if the machine is configured to hibernate.
trans-unit.target: The gateway installation prompts a message if the machine is configured to hibernate.

trans-unit.source: Due to the fact that copy activity runs happen on a specific frequency, the resource usage (CPU, memory) on the machine also follows the same pattern with peak and idle times.
trans-unit.target: Due to the fact that copy activity runs happen on a specific frequency, the resource usage (CPU, memory) on the machine also follows the same pattern with peak and idle times.

trans-unit.source: Resource utilization also depends heavily on the amount of data being moved.
trans-unit.target: Resource utilization also depends heavily on the amount of data being moved.

trans-unit.source: When multiple copy jobs are in progress you will observe resource usage go up during peak times.
trans-unit.target: When multiple copy jobs are in progress you will observe resource usage go up during peak times.

trans-unit.source: While above is the minimum configuration it is always better to have a configuration with more resources than the min configuration described above depending on your specific load for data movement.
trans-unit.target: While above is the minimum configuration it is always better to have a configuration with more resources than the min configuration described above depending on your specific load for data movement.

trans-unit.source: Installation
trans-unit.target: Installation

trans-unit.source: Data Management Gateway can be installed by downloading an MSI setup package from the Microsoft Download Center.
trans-unit.target: Data Management Gateway can be installed by downloading an MSI setup package from the Microsoft Download Center.

trans-unit.source: The MSI can also be used to upgrade existing Data Management Gateway to the latest version, with all settings preserved.
trans-unit.target: The MSI can also be used to upgrade existing Data Management Gateway to the latest version, with all settings preserved.

trans-unit.source: You can find the link to the MSI package from Azure portal by following the step by step walkthrough below.
trans-unit.target: You can find the link to the MSI package from Azure portal by following the step by step walkthrough below.

trans-unit.source: Installation Best practices:
trans-unit.target: Installation Best practices:

trans-unit.source: Configure power plan on the host machine for the gateway so that the machine does not hibernate.
trans-unit.target: Configure power plan on the host machine for the gateway so that the machine does not hibernate.

trans-unit.source: If the host machine hibernates, the gateway won’t be able to respond to data requests.
trans-unit.target: If the host machine hibernates, the gateway won’t be able to respond to data requests.

trans-unit.source: You should backup the certificate associated with the gateway.
trans-unit.target: You should backup the certificate associated with the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Installation Troubleshooting:
trans-unit.target: Installation Troubleshooting:

trans-unit.source: If your company uses a firewall or proxy server, additional steps may be required in case Data Management Gateway cannot connect to Microsoft cloud services.
trans-unit.target: If your company uses a firewall or proxy server, additional steps may be required in case Data Management Gateway cannot connect to Microsoft cloud services.

trans-unit.source: Looking at Gateway logs with Event Viewer:
trans-unit.target: Looking at Gateway logs with Event Viewer:

trans-unit.source: Gaetway configuration manager application shows status for gateway like “Disconnected” or “Connecting”.
trans-unit.target: Gaetway configuration manager application shows status for gateway like “Disconnected” or “Connecting”.

trans-unit.source: For more detailed information you can look at gateway logs in Windows event logs.
trans-unit.target: For more detailed information you can look at gateway logs in Windows event logs.

trans-unit.source: You can find them by using Windows Event Viewer under Application and Services Logs > Data Management Gateway While troubleshooting gateway related issues look for error level events in the event viewer.
trans-unit.target: You can find them by using Windows Event Viewer under Application and Services Logs > Data Management Gateway While troubleshooting gateway related issues look for error level events in the event viewer.

trans-unit.source: Possible symptoms for firewall related issues:
trans-unit.target: Possible symptoms for firewall related issues:

trans-unit.source: When you try to register the gateway, you receive the following error: "Failed to register the gateway key.
trans-unit.target: When you try to register the gateway, you receive the following error: "Failed to register the gateway key.

trans-unit.source: Before trying to register the gateway key again, confirm that the Data Management Gateway is in a connected state and the Data Management Gateway Host Service is Started."
trans-unit.target: Before trying to register the gateway key again, confirm that the Data Management Gateway is in a connected state and the Data Management Gateway Host Service is Started."

trans-unit.source: When you open Configuration Manager, you see status as “Disconnected” or “Connecting”.
trans-unit.target: When you open Configuration Manager, you see status as “Disconnected” or “Connecting”.

trans-unit.source: When viewing Windows event logs, under “Event Viewer” > “Application and Services Logs” > “Data Management Gateway” you see error messages such as “Unable to connect to the remote server” or “A component of Data Management Gateway has become unresponsive and will restart automatically.
trans-unit.target: When viewing Windows event logs, under “Event Viewer” > “Application and Services Logs” > “Data Management Gateway” you see error messages such as “Unable to connect to the remote server” or “A component of Data Management Gateway has become unresponsive and will restart automatically.

trans-unit.source: Component name: Gateway.”
trans-unit.target: Component name: Gateway.”

trans-unit.source: These are caused by the improper configuration of the firewall or proxy server, which blocks Data Management Gateway from connecting to cloud services to authenticate itself.
trans-unit.target: These are caused by the improper configuration of the firewall or proxy server, which blocks Data Management Gateway from connecting to cloud services to authenticate itself.

trans-unit.source: The two firewalls that are possibly in scope are: corporate firewall running on the central router of the organization, and Windows firewall configured as a daemon on the local machine where the gateway is installed.
trans-unit.target: The two firewalls that are possibly in scope are: corporate firewall running on the central router of the organization, and Windows firewall configured as a daemon on the local machine where the gateway is installed.

trans-unit.source: Here are the some considerations:
trans-unit.target: Here are the some considerations:

trans-unit.source: There is no need to change the inbound policy for corporate firewall.
trans-unit.target: There is no need to change the inbound policy for corporate firewall.

trans-unit.source: Both corporate firewall and Windows firewall should enable outbound rule for TCP ports: 80, 440, and from 9305 to 9354.
trans-unit.target: Both corporate firewall and Windows firewall should enable outbound rule for TCP ports: 80, 440, and from 9305 to 9354.

trans-unit.source: These are used by Microsoft Azure Service Bus to establish connection between the cloud services and Data Management Gateway.
trans-unit.target: These are used by Microsoft Azure Service Bus to establish connection between the cloud services and Data Management Gateway.

trans-unit.source: The MSI setup will automatically configure Windows firewall rules for inbound ports for the gateway machine (see ports and security considerations section above).
trans-unit.target: The MSI setup will automatically configure Windows firewall rules for inbound ports for the gateway machine (see ports and security considerations section above).

trans-unit.source: But the setup assumes the above mentioned outbound ports are allowed by default on the local machine and corporate firewall.
trans-unit.target: But the setup assumes the above mentioned outbound ports are allowed by default on the local machine and corporate firewall.

trans-unit.source: You need to enable these outbound ports if that is not the case.
trans-unit.target: You need to enable these outbound ports if that is not the case.

trans-unit.source: If you have replaced the Windows firewall with a third party firewall, these ports might need to be opened manually.
trans-unit.target: If you have replaced the Windows firewall with a third party firewall, these ports might need to be opened manually.

trans-unit.source: If your company uses a proxy server, then you need to add Microsoft Azure to the whitelist.
trans-unit.target: If your company uses a proxy server, then you need to add Microsoft Azure to the whitelist.

trans-unit.source: You can download a list of valid Microsoft Azure IP addresses from the <link><linkText>Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can download a list of valid Microsoft Azure IP addresses from the <link><linkText>Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Using the Data Gateway – Step by Step Walkthrough
trans-unit.target: Using the Data Gateway – Step by Step Walkthrough

trans-unit.source: In this walkthrough, you create a data factory with a pipeline that moves data from an on-premises SQL Server database to an Azure blob.
trans-unit.target: In this walkthrough, you create a data factory with a pipeline that moves data from an on-premises SQL Server database to an Azure blob.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create an Azure data factory
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create an Azure data factory

trans-unit.source: In this step, you use the Azure Management Portal to create an Azure Data Factory instance named ADFTutorialOnPremDF.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you use the Azure Management Portal to create an Azure Data Factory instance named ADFTutorialOnPremDF.

trans-unit.source: You can also create a data factory by using Azure Data Factory cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: You can also create a data factory by using Azure Data Factory cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: After logging into the Azure Preview Portal, click NEW from the bottom-left corner, select Data analytics in the Create blade, and click Data Factory on the Data analytics blade.
trans-unit.target: After logging into the Azure Preview Portal, click NEW from the bottom-left corner, select Data analytics in the Create blade, and click Data Factory on the Data analytics blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New->DataFactory</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New->DataFactory</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the New data factory blade:
trans-unit.target: In the New data factory blade:

trans-unit.source: Enter ADFTutorialOnPremDF for the name.
trans-unit.target: Enter ADFTutorialOnPremDF for the name.

trans-unit.source: Click RESOURCE GROUP NAME and select ADFTutorialResourceGroup.
trans-unit.target: Click RESOURCE GROUP NAME and select ADFTutorialResourceGroup.

trans-unit.source: You can select an existing resource group or create a new one.
trans-unit.target: You can select an existing resource group or create a new one.

trans-unit.source: To create a new resource group:
trans-unit.target: To create a new resource group:

trans-unit.source: Click Create a new resource group.
trans-unit.target: Click Create a new resource group.

trans-unit.source: In the Create resource group blade, enter a name for the resource group, and click OK.
trans-unit.target: In the Create resource group blade, enter a name for the resource group, and click OK.

trans-unit.source: Note that Add to Startboard is checked on the New data factory blade.
trans-unit.target: Note that Add to Startboard is checked on the New data factory blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add to Startboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add to Startboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the New data factory blade, click Create.
trans-unit.target: In the New data factory blade, click Create.

trans-unit.source: The name of the Azure data factory must be globally unique.
trans-unit.target: The name of the Azure data factory must be globally unique.

trans-unit.source: If you receive the error: Data factory name “ADFTutorialOnPremDF” is not available, change the name of the data factory (for example, yournameADFTutorialOnPremDF) and try creating again.
trans-unit.target: If you receive the error: Data factory name “ADFTutorialOnPremDF” is not available, change the name of the data factory (for example, yournameADFTutorialOnPremDF) and try creating again.

trans-unit.source: Use this name in place of ADFTutorialOnPremDF while performing remaining steps in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Use this name in place of ADFTutorialOnPremDF while performing remaining steps in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Look for notifications from the creation process in the NOTIFICATIONS hub on the left.
trans-unit.target: Look for notifications from the creation process in the NOTIFICATIONS hub on the left.

trans-unit.source: Click X to close the NOTIFCATIONS blade if it is open.
trans-unit.target: Click X to close the NOTIFCATIONS blade if it is open.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>NOTIFICATIONS hub</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>NOTIFICATIONS hub</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After creation is complete, you will see the Data Factory blade as shown below:
trans-unit.target: After creation is complete, you will see the Data Factory blade as shown below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data Factory Home Page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data Factory Home Page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create a data management gateway
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create a data management gateway

trans-unit.source: On the Data Factory blade for ADFTutorialOnPremDF, click Linked Services.
trans-unit.target: On the Data Factory blade for ADFTutorialOnPremDF, click Linked Services.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data Factory Home Page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data Factory Home Page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Linked Services blade, click + Data gateway.
trans-unit.target: On the Linked Services blade, click + Data gateway.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Linked Services - Add a Gateway button</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Linked Services - Add a Gateway button</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Create blade, enter adftutorialgateway for the name, and click OK.
trans-unit.target: In the Create blade, enter adftutorialgateway for the name, and click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create Gateway blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create Gateway blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Configure blade, click Install directly on this computer.
trans-unit.target: In the Configure blade, click Install directly on this computer.

trans-unit.source: This will download the installation package for the gateway, install, configure, and register the gateway on the computer.
trans-unit.target: This will download the installation package for the gateway, install, configure, and register the gateway on the computer.

trans-unit.source: Please use Internet Explorer or a Microsoft ClickOnce compatible web browser.
trans-unit.target: Please use Internet Explorer or a Microsoft ClickOnce compatible web browser.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Gateway - Configure blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Gateway - Configure blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This is the easiest way (one-click) to download, install, configure, and register the gateway in one single step.
trans-unit.target: This is the easiest way (one-click) to download, install, configure, and register the gateway in one single step.

trans-unit.source: You can see the Microsoft Data Management Gateway Configuration Manager application is installed on your computer.
trans-unit.target: You can see the Microsoft Data Management Gateway Configuration Manager application is installed on your computer.

trans-unit.source: You can also find the executable ConfigManager.exe in the folder: C:\Program Files\Microsoft Data Management Gateway\1.0\Shared.
trans-unit.target: You can also find the executable ConfigManager.exe in the folder: C:\Program Files\Microsoft Data Management Gateway\1.0\Shared.

trans-unit.source: You can also download and install gateway manually by using the links in this blade and register it using the key shown in the REGISTER WITH KEY text box.
trans-unit.target: You can also download and install gateway manually by using the links in this blade and register it using the key shown in the REGISTER WITH KEY text box.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Data Management Gateway</linkText><title></title></link> section for details about the gateway including best practices and important considerations.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Data Management Gateway</linkText><title></title></link> section for details about the gateway including best practices and important considerations.

trans-unit.source: You must be an administrator on the local computer to install and configure the Data Management Gateway successfully.
trans-unit.target: You must be an administrator on the local computer to install and configure the Data Management Gateway successfully.

trans-unit.source: You can add additional users to the Data Management Gateway Users local Windows group.
trans-unit.target: You can add additional users to the Data Management Gateway Users local Windows group.

trans-unit.source: The members of this group will be able to use the Data Management Gateway Configuration Manager tool to configure the gateway.
trans-unit.target: The members of this group will be able to use the Data Management Gateway Configuration Manager tool to configure the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Click the NOTIFICATIONS hub on the left.
trans-unit.target: Click the NOTIFICATIONS hub on the left.

trans-unit.source: Wait until you see Express setup for 'adftutorialgateway' succeeded message in the Notifications blade.
trans-unit.target: Wait until you see Express setup for 'adftutorialgateway' succeeded message in the Notifications blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Express setup succeeded</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Express setup succeeded</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click OK on the Create blade and then on the New data gateway blade.
trans-unit.target: Click OK on the Create blade and then on the New data gateway blade.

trans-unit.source: Close the Linked Services blade (by pressing X button in the top-right corner) and reopen the Linked Services blade to see the latest status of the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Close the Linked Services blade (by pressing X button in the top-right corner) and reopen the Linked Services blade to see the latest status of the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Confirm that the status of the gateway is Online.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that the status of the gateway is Online.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Gateway status</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Gateway status</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Launch Microsoft Data Management Gateway Configuration Manager application on your computer.
trans-unit.target: Launch Microsoft Data Management Gateway Configuration Manager application on your computer.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Gateway Configuration Manager</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Gateway Configuration Manager</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Wait until the values are set as follows :
trans-unit.target: Wait until the values are set as follows :

trans-unit.source: If the Service status is not set to Started, click Start service to start the service and wait for a minute for the other fields to refresh.
trans-unit.target: If the Service status is not set to Started, click Start service to start the service and wait for a minute for the other fields to refresh.

trans-unit.source: Gateway name is set to adftutorialgateway.
trans-unit.target: Gateway name is set to adftutorialgateway.

trans-unit.source: Instance name is set to adftutorialgateway.
trans-unit.target: Instance name is set to adftutorialgateway.

trans-unit.source: Gateway key status is set to Registered.
trans-unit.target: Gateway key status is set to Registered.

trans-unit.source: The status bar the bottom displays Connected to Data Management Gateway Cloud Service along with a green check mark.
trans-unit.target: The status bar the bottom displays Connected to Data Management Gateway Cloud Service along with a green check mark.

trans-unit.source: Switch to Certificates.
trans-unit.target: Switch to Certificates.

trans-unit.source: The certificate specified on this tab is used to encrypt/decrypt credentials for the on-premises data store that you specify on the portal.
trans-unit.target: The certificate specified on this tab is used to encrypt/decrypt credentials for the on-premises data store that you specify on the portal.

trans-unit.source: Click Change to use your own certificate instead.
trans-unit.target: Click Change to use your own certificate instead.

trans-unit.source: By default, the gateway uses the certificate that is auto-generated by the Data Factory service.
trans-unit.target: By default, the gateway uses the certificate that is auto-generated by the Data Factory service.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Gateway certificate configuration</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Gateway certificate configuration</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the portal, on the Linked Services blade, confirm that the status of the gateway is Good.
trans-unit.target: In the portal, on the Linked Services blade, confirm that the status of the gateway is Good.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create linked services
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create linked services

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create two linked services: StorageLinkedService and SqlServerLinkedService.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create two linked services: StorageLinkedService and SqlServerLinkedService.

trans-unit.source: The SqlServerLinkedService links an on-premises SQL Server database and the StorageLinkedService linked service links an Azure blob store to the ADFTutorialDataFactory.
trans-unit.target: The SqlServerLinkedService links an on-premises SQL Server database and the StorageLinkedService linked service links an Azure blob store to the ADFTutorialDataFactory.

trans-unit.source: You will create a pipeline later in this walkthrough that copies data from the on-premises SQL Server database to the Azure blob store.
trans-unit.target: You will create a pipeline later in this walkthrough that copies data from the on-premises SQL Server database to the Azure blob store.

trans-unit.source: Add a linked service to an on-premises SQL Server database
trans-unit.target: Add a linked service to an on-premises SQL Server database

trans-unit.source: In the Linked Services blade, click New data store on the command bar.
trans-unit.target: In the Linked Services blade, click New data store on the command bar.

trans-unit.source: Enter SqlServerLinkedService for the name.
trans-unit.target: Enter SqlServerLinkedService for the name.

trans-unit.source: Click arrow next to the Type, and select SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: Click arrow next to the Type, and select SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create new data store</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create new data store</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You should more settings below the Type setting.
trans-unit.target: You should more settings below the Type setting.

trans-unit.source: For the Data gateway setting, select the gateway you just created.
trans-unit.target: For the Data gateway setting, select the gateway you just created.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SQL Server settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SQL Server settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Enter the name of your database server for the Server setting.
trans-unit.target: Enter the name of your database server for the Server setting.

trans-unit.source: Enter the name of the database for the Database setting.
trans-unit.target: Enter the name of the database for the Database setting.

trans-unit.source: Click arrow next to Credentials.
trans-unit.target: Click arrow next to Credentials.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Credentials blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Credentials blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Credentials blade, click Click here to set credentials.
trans-unit.target: In the Credentials blade, click Click here to set credentials.

trans-unit.source: In the Setting Credentials dialog box, do the following:
trans-unit.target: In the Setting Credentials dialog box, do the following:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Setting credentials dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Setting credentials dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select authentication that you want the Data Factory service to use to connect to the database.
trans-unit.target: Select authentication that you want the Data Factory service to use to connect to the database.

trans-unit.source: Enter name of the user who has access to the database for the USERNAME setting.
trans-unit.target: Enter name of the user who has access to the database for the USERNAME setting.

trans-unit.source: Enter password for the user for the PASSWORD setting.
trans-unit.target: Enter password for the user for the PASSWORD setting.

trans-unit.source: Click OK to close the dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to close the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: Click OK to close the Credentials blade.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to close the Credentials blade.

trans-unit.source: Click OK on the New data store blade.
trans-unit.target: Click OK on the New data store blade.

trans-unit.source: Confirm that the status for SqlServerLinkedService is set to Online in the Linked Services blade.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that the status for SqlServerLinkedService is set to Online in the Linked Services blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SQL Server linked service status</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SQL Server linked service status</linkText>

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Setting Credentials and Security</linkText><title></title></link> section for more details about setting credentials.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Setting Credentials and Security</linkText><title></title></link> section for more details about setting credentials.

trans-unit.source: Add a linked service for an Azure storage account
trans-unit.target: Add a linked service for an Azure storage account

trans-unit.source: In the Linked Services blade, click New datastore on the toolbar.
trans-unit.target: In the Linked Services blade, click New datastore on the toolbar.

trans-unit.source: Enter StorageLinkedService for the Name field.
trans-unit.target: Enter StorageLinkedService for the Name field.

trans-unit.source: Click arrow next to Type and select Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Click arrow next to Type and select Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: You should see new fields: Account name and Account key under Type setting now.
trans-unit.target: You should see new fields: Account name and Account key under Type setting now.

trans-unit.source: Enter the name of your Azure storage account for the Account name.
trans-unit.target: Enter the name of your Azure storage account for the Account name.

trans-unit.source: Enter the key for your Azure storage account for the Account key.
trans-unit.target: Enter the key for your Azure storage account for the Account key.

trans-unit.source: Click OK to close the dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to close the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Create input and output datasets
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Create input and output datasets

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create input and output datasets that represent input and output data for the copy operation (On-premises SQL Server database => Azure blob storage).
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create input and output datasets that represent input and output data for the copy operation (On-premises SQL Server database => Azure blob storage).

trans-unit.source: Before creating datasets or tables (rectangular datasets), you need to do the following (detailed steps follows the list):
trans-unit.target: Before creating datasets or tables (rectangular datasets), you need to do the following (detailed steps follows the list):

trans-unit.source: Create a table named emp in the SQL Server Database you added as a linked service to the data factory and insert couple of sample entries into the table.
trans-unit.target: Create a table named emp in the SQL Server Database you added as a linked service to the data factory and insert couple of sample entries into the table.

trans-unit.source: Create a blob container named adftutorial in the Azure blob storage account you added as a linked service to the data factory.
trans-unit.target: Create a blob container named adftutorial in the Azure blob storage account you added as a linked service to the data factory.

trans-unit.source: Prepare On-premises SQL Server for the tutorial
trans-unit.target: Prepare On-premises SQL Server for the tutorial

trans-unit.source: In the database you specified for the on-premises SQL Server linked service (SqlServerLinkedService), use the following SQL script to create the emp table in the database.
trans-unit.target: In the database you specified for the on-premises SQL Server linked service (SqlServerLinkedService), use the following SQL script to create the emp table in the database.

trans-unit.source: Insert some sample into the table:
trans-unit.target: Insert some sample into the table:

trans-unit.source: Create input table
trans-unit.target: Create input table

trans-unit.source: In the DATA FACTORY blade, click Author and deploy tile to launch the Editor for the data factory.
trans-unit.target: In the DATA FACTORY blade, click Author and deploy tile to launch the Editor for the data factory.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Author and Deploy Tile</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Author and Deploy Tile</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Data Factory Editor, click New dataset on the command bar, and click On-premises SQL.
trans-unit.target: In the Data Factory Editor, click New dataset on the command bar, and click On-premises SQL.

trans-unit.source: Replace the JSON in the right pane with the following text:
trans-unit.target: Replace the JSON in the right pane with the following text:

trans-unit.source: Note the following:
trans-unit.target: Note the following:

trans-unit.source: type is set to SqlServerTable.
trans-unit.target: type is set to SqlServerTable.

trans-unit.source: tableName is set to emp.
trans-unit.target: tableName is set to emp.

trans-unit.source: linkedServiceName is set to SqlServerLinkedService (you had created this linked service in Step 2).
trans-unit.target: linkedServiceName is set to SqlServerLinkedService (you had created this linked service in Step 2).

trans-unit.source: For an input table that is not generated by another pipeline in Azure Data Factory, you must set external to true.
trans-unit.target: For an input table that is not generated by another pipeline in Azure Data Factory, you must set external to true.

trans-unit.source: It denotes the input data is produced external to the Azure Data Factory service.
trans-unit.target: It denotes the input data is produced external to the Azure Data Factory service.

trans-unit.source: You can optionally specify any external data policies using the externalData element in the Policy section.
trans-unit.target: You can optionally specify any external data policies using the externalData element in the Policy section.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>JSON Scripting Reference[json-script-reference]</linkText><title></title></link> for details about JSON properties.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>JSON Scripting Reference[json-script-reference]</linkText><title></title></link> for details about JSON properties.

trans-unit.source: Click Deploy on the command bar to deploy the dataset (table is a rectangular dataset).
trans-unit.target: Click Deploy on the command bar to deploy the dataset (table is a rectangular dataset).

trans-unit.source: Confirm that you see a message on the title bar that says TABLE DEPLOYED SUCCESSFULLY.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that you see a message on the title bar that says TABLE DEPLOYED SUCCESSFULLY.

trans-unit.source: Create output table
trans-unit.target: Create output table

trans-unit.source: In the Data Factory Editor, click New dataset on the command bar, and click Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: In the Data Factory Editor, click New dataset on the command bar, and click Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: Replace the JSON in the right pane with the following text:
trans-unit.target: Replace the JSON in the right pane with the following text:

trans-unit.source: Note the following:
trans-unit.target: Note the following:

trans-unit.source: type is set to AzureBlob.
trans-unit.target: type is set to AzureBlob.

trans-unit.source: linkedServiceName is set to StorageLinkedService (you had created this linked service in Step 2).
trans-unit.target: linkedServiceName is set to StorageLinkedService (you had created this linked service in Step 2).

trans-unit.source: folderPath is set to adftutorial/outfromonpremdf where outfromonpremdf is the folder in the adftutorial container.
trans-unit.target: folderPath is set to adftutorial/outfromonpremdf where outfromonpremdf is the folder in the adftutorial container.

trans-unit.source: You just need to create the adftutorial container.
trans-unit.target: You just need to create the adftutorial container.

trans-unit.source: The availability is set to hourly (frequency set to hour and interval set to 1).
trans-unit.target: The availability is set to hourly (frequency set to hour and interval set to 1).

trans-unit.source: The Data Factory service will generate an output data slice every hour in the emp table in the Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: The Data Factory service will generate an output data slice every hour in the emp table in the Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: if you don't specify a fileName for an input table, all files/blobs from the input folder (folderPath) are considered as inputs.
trans-unit.target: if you don't specify a fileName for an input table, all files/blobs from the input folder (folderPath) are considered as inputs.

trans-unit.source: If you specify a fileName in the JSON, only the specified file/blob is considered asn input.
trans-unit.target: If you specify a fileName in the JSON, only the specified file/blob is considered asn input.

trans-unit.source: See the sample files in the <link><linkText>tutorial[adf-tutorial]</linkText><title></title></link> for examples.
trans-unit.target: See the sample files in the <link><linkText>tutorial[adf-tutorial]</linkText><title></title></link> for examples.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify a fileName for an output table, the generated files in the folderPath are named in the following format: Data..txt (for example: : Data.0a405f8a-93ff-4c6f-b3be-f69616f1df7a.txt.).
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify a fileName for an output table, the generated files in the folderPath are named in the following format: Data..txt (for example: : Data.0a405f8a-93ff-4c6f-b3be-f69616f1df7a.txt.).

trans-unit.source: To set folderPath and fileName dynamically based on the SliceStart time, use the partitionedBy property.
trans-unit.target: To set folderPath and fileName dynamically based on the SliceStart time, use the partitionedBy property.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, folderPath uses Year, Month, and Day from from the SliceStart (start time of the slice being processed) and fileName uses Hour from the SliceStart.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, folderPath uses Year, Month, and Day from from the SliceStart (start time of the slice being processed) and fileName uses Hour from the SliceStart.

trans-unit.source: For example, if a slice is being produced for 2014-10-20T08:00:00, the folderName is set to wikidatagateway/wikisampledataout/2014/10/20 and the fileName is set to 08.csv.
trans-unit.target: For example, if a slice is being produced for 2014-10-20T08:00:00, the folderName is set to wikidatagateway/wikisampledataout/2014/10/20 and the fileName is set to 08.csv.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>JSON Scripting Reference[json-script-reference]</linkText><title></title></link> for details about JSON properties.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>JSON Scripting Reference[json-script-reference]</linkText><title></title></link> for details about JSON properties.

trans-unit.source: Click Deploy on the command bar to deploy the dataset (table is a rectangular dataset).
trans-unit.target: Click Deploy on the command bar to deploy the dataset (table is a rectangular dataset).

trans-unit.source: Confirm that you see a message on the title bar that says TABLE DEPLOYED SUCCESSFULLY.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that you see a message on the title bar that says TABLE DEPLOYED SUCCESSFULLY.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Create and run a pipeline
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Create and run a pipeline

trans-unit.source: In this step, you create a pipeline with one Copy Activity that uses EmpOnPremSQLTable as input and OutputBlobTable as output.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you create a pipeline with one Copy Activity that uses EmpOnPremSQLTable as input and OutputBlobTable as output.

trans-unit.source: In the DATA FACTORY blade, click Author and deploy tile to launch the Editor for the data factory.
trans-unit.target: In the DATA FACTORY blade, click Author and deploy tile to launch the Editor for the data factory.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Author and Deploy Tile</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Author and Deploy Tile</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click New pipeline on the command bar.
trans-unit.target: Click New pipeline on the command bar.

trans-unit.source: If you do not see the button, click ... (ellipsis) to expand the command bar.
trans-unit.target: If you do not see the button, click ... (ellipsis) to expand the command bar.

trans-unit.source: Replace the JSON in the right pane with the following text:
trans-unit.target: Replace the JSON in the right pane with the following text:

trans-unit.source: Note the following:
trans-unit.target: Note the following:

trans-unit.source: In the activities section, there is only activity whose type is set to Copy.
trans-unit.target: In the activities section, there is only activity whose type is set to Copy.

trans-unit.source: Input for the activity is set to EmpOnPremSQLTable and output for the activity is set to OutputBlobTable.
trans-unit.target: Input for the activity is set to EmpOnPremSQLTable and output for the activity is set to OutputBlobTable.

trans-unit.source: In the transformation section, SqlSource is specified as the source type and BlobSink **is specified as the **sink type.
trans-unit.target: In the transformation section, SqlSource is specified as the source type and BlobSink **is specified as the **sink type.

trans-unit.source: SQL query select * from emp is specified for the sqlReaderQuery property of SqlSource.
trans-unit.target: SQL query select * from emp is specified for the sqlReaderQuery property of SqlSource.

trans-unit.source: Replace the value of the start property with the current day and end value with the next day.
trans-unit.target: Replace the value of the start property with the current day and end value with the next day.

trans-unit.source: Both start and end datetimes must be in <link><linkText>ISO format</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Both start and end datetimes must be in <link><linkText>ISO format</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The end time is optional, but we will use it in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: The end time is optional, but we will use it in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify value for the end property, it is calculated as "start + 48 hours".
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify value for the end property, it is calculated as "start + 48 hours".

trans-unit.source: To run the pipeline indefinitely, specify 9/9/9999 as the value for the end property.
trans-unit.target: To run the pipeline indefinitely, specify 9/9/9999 as the value for the end property.

trans-unit.source: You are defining the time duration in which the data slices will be processed based on the Availability properties that were defined for each Azure Data Factory table.
trans-unit.target: You are defining the time duration in which the data slices will be processed based on the Availability properties that were defined for each Azure Data Factory table.

trans-unit.source: In the example above, there will be 24 data slices as each data slice is produced hourly.
trans-unit.target: In the example above, there will be 24 data slices as each data slice is produced hourly.

trans-unit.source: Click Deploy on the command bar to deploy the dataset (table is a rectangular dataset).
trans-unit.target: Click Deploy on the command bar to deploy the dataset (table is a rectangular dataset).

trans-unit.source: Confirm that you see a message on the title bar that says PIPELINE DEPLOYED SUCCESSFULLY.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that you see a message on the title bar that says PIPELINE DEPLOYED SUCCESSFULLY.

trans-unit.source: Now, close the Editor blade by clicking X.
trans-unit.target: Now, close the Editor blade by clicking X.

trans-unit.source: Click X again to close the ADFTutorialDataFactory blade with the toolbar and tree view.
trans-unit.target: Click X again to close the ADFTutorialDataFactory blade with the toolbar and tree view.

trans-unit.source: If you see your unsaved edits will be discarded message, click OK.
trans-unit.target: If you see your unsaved edits will be discarded message, click OK.

trans-unit.source: You should be back to the DATA FACTORY blade for the ADFTutorialOnPremDF.
trans-unit.target: You should be back to the DATA FACTORY blade for the ADFTutorialOnPremDF.

trans-unit.source: Congratulations! You have successfully created an Azure data factory, linked services, tables, and a pipeline and scheduled the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Congratulations! You have successfully created an Azure data factory, linked services, tables, and a pipeline and scheduled the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: View the data factory in a Diagram View
trans-unit.target: View the data factory in a Diagram View

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Preview Portal, click Diagram tile on the home page for the ADFTutorialOnPremDF data factory.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Preview Portal, click Diagram tile on the home page for the ADFTutorialOnPremDF data factory.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Diagram Link</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Diagram Link</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You should see the diagram similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should see the diagram similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Diagram View</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Diagram View</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can zoom in, zoom out, zoom to 100%, zoom to fit, automatically position pipelines and tables, and show lineage information (highlights upstream and downstream items of selected items).
trans-unit.target: You can zoom in, zoom out, zoom to 100%, zoom to fit, automatically position pipelines and tables, and show lineage information (highlights upstream and downstream items of selected items).

trans-unit.source: You can double-blick on an object (input/output table or pipeline) to see properties for it.
trans-unit.target: You can double-blick on an object (input/output table or pipeline) to see properties for it.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Monitor the datasets and pipelines
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Monitor the datasets and pipelines

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will use the Azure Portal to monitor what’s going on in an Azure data factory.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will use the Azure Portal to monitor what’s going on in an Azure data factory.

trans-unit.source: You can also use PowerShell cmdlets to monitor datasets and pipelines.
trans-unit.target: You can also use PowerShell cmdlets to monitor datasets and pipelines.

trans-unit.source: For details about monitoring, see <link><linkText>Monitor and Manage Pipelines</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For details about monitoring, see <link><linkText>Monitor and Manage Pipelines</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to Azure Preview Portal (if you have closed it)
trans-unit.target: Navigate to Azure Preview Portal (if you have closed it)

trans-unit.source: If the blade for ADFTutorialOnPremDF is not open, open it by clicking ADFTutorialOnPremDF on the Startboard.
trans-unit.target: If the blade for ADFTutorialOnPremDF is not open, open it by clicking ADFTutorialOnPremDF on the Startboard.

trans-unit.source: You should see the count and names of tables and pipeline you created on this blade.
trans-unit.target: You should see the count and names of tables and pipeline you created on this blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data Factory Home Page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data Factory Home Page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Now, click Datasets tile.
trans-unit.target: Now, click Datasets tile.

trans-unit.source: On the Datasets blade, click the EmpOnPremSQLTable.
trans-unit.target: On the Datasets blade, click the EmpOnPremSQLTable.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>EmpOnPremSQLTable slices</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>EmpOnPremSQLTable slices</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Notice that the data slices up to the current time have already been produced and they are Ready.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the data slices up to the current time have already been produced and they are Ready.

trans-unit.source: It is because you have inserted the data in the SQL Server database and it is there all the time.
trans-unit.target: It is because you have inserted the data in the SQL Server database and it is there all the time.

trans-unit.source: Confirm that no slices show up in the Problem slices section at the bottom.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that no slices show up in the Problem slices section at the bottom.

trans-unit.source: Both Recently updated slices and Recently failed slices lists are sorted by the LAST UPDATE TIME.
trans-unit.target: Both Recently updated slices and Recently failed slices lists are sorted by the LAST UPDATE TIME.

trans-unit.source: The update time of a slice is changed in the following situations.
trans-unit.target: The update time of a slice is changed in the following situations.

trans-unit.source: You update the status of the slice manually, for example, by using the Set-AzureDataFactorySliceStatus (or) by clicking RUN on the SLICE blade for the slice.
trans-unit.target: You update the status of the slice manually, for example, by using the Set-AzureDataFactorySliceStatus (or) by clicking RUN on the SLICE blade for the slice.

trans-unit.source: The slice changes status due to an execution (e.g. a run started, a run ended and failed, a run ended and succeeded, etc).
trans-unit.target: The slice changes status due to an execution (e.g. a run started, a run ended and failed, a run ended and succeeded, etc).

trans-unit.source: Click on the title of the lists or ... (ellipses) to see the larger list of slices.
trans-unit.target: Click on the title of the lists or ... (ellipses) to see the larger list of slices.

trans-unit.source: Click Filter on the toolbar to filter the slices.
trans-unit.target: Click Filter on the toolbar to filter the slices.

trans-unit.source: To view the data slices sorted by the slice start/end times instead, click Data slices (by slice time) tile.
trans-unit.target: To view the data slices sorted by the slice start/end times instead, click Data slices (by slice time) tile.

trans-unit.source: Now, In the Datasets blade, click OutputBlobTable.
trans-unit.target: Now, In the Datasets blade, click OutputBlobTable.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>OputputBlobTable slices</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>OputputBlobTable slices</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Confirm that slices up to the current time are produced and Ready.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that slices up to the current time are produced and Ready.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the statuses of slices up to the current time are set to Ready.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the statuses of slices up to the current time are set to Ready.

trans-unit.source: Click on any data slice from the list and you should see the DATA SLICE blade.
trans-unit.target: Click on any data slice from the list and you should see the DATA SLICE blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data Slice Blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data Slice Blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If the slice is not in the Ready state, you can see the upstream slices that are not Ready and are blocking the current slice from executing in the Upstream slices that are not ready list.
trans-unit.target: If the slice is not in the Ready state, you can see the upstream slices that are not Ready and are blocking the current slice from executing in the Upstream slices that are not ready list.

trans-unit.source: Click on the activity run from the list at the bottom to see activity run details.
trans-unit.target: Click on the activity run from the list at the bottom to see activity run details.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Activity Run Details blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Activity Run Details blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click X to close all the blades until you
trans-unit.target: Click X to close all the blades until you

trans-unit.source: get back to the home blade for the ADFTutorialOnPremDF.
trans-unit.target: get back to the home blade for the ADFTutorialOnPremDF.

trans-unit.source: (optional) Click Pipelines, click ADFTutorialOnPremDF, and drill through input tables (Consumed) or output tables (Produced).
trans-unit.target: (optional) Click Pipelines, click ADFTutorialOnPremDF, and drill through input tables (Consumed) or output tables (Produced).

trans-unit.source: Use tools such as Azure Storage Explorer to verify the output.
trans-unit.target: Use tools such as Azure Storage Explorer to verify the output.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Storage Explorer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Storage Explorer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Setting Credentials and Security
trans-unit.target: Setting Credentials and Security

trans-unit.source: If you access the portal from a machine that is different from the gateway machine, you must make sure that the Credentials Manager application can connect to the gateway machine.
trans-unit.target: If you access the portal from a machine that is different from the gateway machine, you must make sure that the Credentials Manager application can connect to the gateway machine.

trans-unit.source: If the application cannot reach the gateway machine, it will not allow you to set credentials for the data source and to test connection to the data source.
trans-unit.target: If the application cannot reach the gateway machine, it will not allow you to set credentials for the data source and to test connection to the data source.

trans-unit.source: When you use the “Setting Credentials” application launched from Azure Portal to set credentials for an on-premises data source, the portal encrypts the credentials with the certificate you specified in the Certificate tab of the Data Management Gateway Configuration Manager on the gateway machine.
trans-unit.target: When you use the “Setting Credentials” application launched from Azure Portal to set credentials for an on-premises data source, the portal encrypts the credentials with the certificate you specified in the Certificate tab of the Data Management Gateway Configuration Manager on the gateway machine.

trans-unit.source: If you are looking for an API based approach for encrypting the credentials you can use the <link><linkText>New-AzureDataFactoryEncryptValue</linkText><title></title></link> PowerShell cmdlet to encrypt credentials.
trans-unit.target: If you are looking for an API based approach for encrypting the credentials you can use the <link><linkText>New-AzureDataFactoryEncryptValue</linkText><title></title></link> PowerShell cmdlet to encrypt credentials.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet uses the certificate that gateway is configured to use to encrypt the credentials.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet uses the certificate that gateway is configured to use to encrypt the credentials.

trans-unit.source: You can the encrypted credentials returned by this cmdlet and add it to EncryptedCredential element of the connectionString in the JSON file that you will use with the <link><linkText>New-AzureDataFactoryLinkedService</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet or in the JSON snippet in the Data Factory Editor in the portal.
trans-unit.target: You can the encrypted credentials returned by this cmdlet and add it to EncryptedCredential element of the connectionString in the JSON file that you will use with the <link><linkText>New-AzureDataFactoryLinkedService</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet or in the JSON snippet in the Data Factory Editor in the portal.

trans-unit.source: Note: If you use the “Setting Credentials” application it automatically sets the encrypted credentials in the linked service as shown above.
trans-unit.target: Note: If you use the “Setting Credentials” application it automatically sets the encrypted credentials in the linked service as shown above.

trans-unit.source: There is one more approach for setting credentials using Data Factory Editor.
trans-unit.target: There is one more approach for setting credentials using Data Factory Editor.

trans-unit.source: If you create a SQL Server linked service by using the editor and you enter credentials in plain text, the credentials are encrypted using a certificate that the Data Factory service owns, NOT the certificate that gateway is configured to use.
trans-unit.target: If you create a SQL Server linked service by using the editor and you enter credentials in plain text, the credentials are encrypted using a certificate that the Data Factory service owns, NOT the certificate that gateway is configured to use.

trans-unit.source: While this approach might be a little faster in some cases it is less secure.
trans-unit.target: While this approach might be a little faster in some cases it is less secure.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, we recommend that you follow this approach only for development/testing purposes.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, we recommend that you follow this approach only for development/testing purposes.

trans-unit.source: Creating and registering a gateway using Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Creating and registering a gateway using Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: This section describes how to create and register a gateway using Azure PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: This section describes how to create and register a gateway using Azure PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: Launch Azure PowerShell in administrator mode.
trans-unit.target: Launch Azure PowerShell in administrator mode.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Data Factory cmdlets are available in the AzureResourceManager mode.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Data Factory cmdlets are available in the AzureResourceManager mode.

trans-unit.source: Execute the following command to switch to the AzureResourceManager mode.
trans-unit.target: Execute the following command to switch to the AzureResourceManager mode.

trans-unit.source: Use the New-AzureDataFactoryGateway cmdlet to create a logical gateway as follows:
trans-unit.target: Use the New-AzureDataFactoryGateway cmdlet to create a logical gateway as follows:

trans-unit.source: Example command and output:
trans-unit.target: Example command and output:

trans-unit.source: Use the New-AzureDataFactoryGatewayKey cmdlet to generate a registration key for the newly created gateway, and store the key in a local variable $Key:
trans-unit.target: Use the New-AzureDataFactoryGatewayKey cmdlet to generate a registration key for the newly created gateway, and store the key in a local variable $Key:

trans-unit.source: Example command output:
trans-unit.target: Example command output:

trans-unit.source: In Azure PowerShell, switch to the folder: C:\Program Files\Microsoft Data Management Gateway\1.0\PowerShellScript\ and Run RegisterGateway.ps1 script associated with the local variable $Key as shown in the following command to register the client agent installed on your machine with the logical gateway you create earlier.
trans-unit.target: In Azure PowerShell, switch to the folder: C:\Program Files\Microsoft Data Management Gateway\1.0\PowerShellScript\ and Run RegisterGateway.ps1 script associated with the local variable $Key as shown in the following command to register the client agent installed on your machine with the logical gateway you create earlier.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Get-AzureDataFactoryGateway cmdlet to get the list of Gateways in your data factory.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Get-AzureDataFactoryGateway cmdlet to get the list of Gateways in your data factory.

trans-unit.source: When the Status shows online, it means your gateway is ready to use.
trans-unit.target: When the Status shows online, it means your gateway is ready to use.

trans-unit.source: You can remove a gateway using the Remove-AzureDataFactoryGateway cmdlet and update description for a gateway using the Set-AzureDataFactoryGateway cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: You can remove a gateway using the Remove-AzureDataFactoryGateway cmdlet and update description for a gateway using the Set-AzureDataFactoryGateway cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: For syntax and other details about these cmdlets, see Data Factory Cmdlet Reference.
trans-unit.target: For syntax and other details about these cmdlets, see Data Factory Cmdlet Reference.

trans-unit.source: Data flow for copy Using Data Management Gateway
trans-unit.target: Data flow for copy Using Data Management Gateway

trans-unit.source: When you use a copy activity in a data pipeline to ingest on-premises data to cloud for further processing, or export result data in the cloud back to an on-premises data store, the copy activity internally uses a gateway to transfer data from on-premises data source to cloud and vice versa.
trans-unit.target: When you use a copy activity in a data pipeline to ingest on-premises data to cloud for further processing, or export result data in the cloud back to an on-premises data store, the copy activity internally uses a gateway to transfer data from on-premises data source to cloud and vice versa.

trans-unit.source: Here high level data flow for and summary of steps for copy with data gateway:
trans-unit.target: Here high level data flow for and summary of steps for copy with data gateway:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data flow using gateway</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data flow using gateway</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Data developer creates a new gateway for an Azure Data Factory using either the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>PowerShell Cmdlet</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Data developer creates a new gateway for an Azure Data Factory using either the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>PowerShell Cmdlet</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Data developer uses “Linked services” panel to define a new linked service for an on-premises data store with the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Data developer uses “Linked services” panel to define a new linked service for an on-premises data store with the gateway.

trans-unit.source: As part of setting up the linked service data developer uses the Setting Credentials application as show in the step by step walkthrough to specify authentication types and credentials.
trans-unit.target: As part of setting up the linked service data developer uses the Setting Credentials application as show in the step by step walkthrough to specify authentication types and credentials.

trans-unit.source: The Setting Credentials application dialog will communicate with the data store to test connection and the gateway to save credentials.
trans-unit.target: The Setting Credentials application dialog will communicate with the data store to test connection and the gateway to save credentials.

trans-unit.source: Gateway will encrypt the credentials with the certificate associated with the gateway (supplied by data developer), before saving the credentials in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Gateway will encrypt the credentials with the certificate associated with the gateway (supplied by data developer), before saving the credentials in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Data factory movement service communicates with the gateway for scheduling & management of jobs via a control channel that uses a shared Azure service bus queue. When copy activity job needs to be kicked off, data factory queues up the request along with credential information. Gateway kicks off the job after polling the queue.
trans-unit.target: Data factory movement service communicates with the gateway for scheduling & management of jobs via a control channel that uses a shared Azure service bus queue. When copy activity job needs to be kicked off, data factory queues up the request along with credential information. Gateway kicks off the job after polling the queue.

trans-unit.source: The gateway decrypts the credentials with the same certificate and then connects to the on-premises data store with the proper authentication type.
trans-unit.target: The gateway decrypts the credentials with the same certificate and then connects to the on-premises data store with the proper authentication type.

trans-unit.source: The gateway copies data from the on-premises store to a cloud storage, or from a cloud storage to an on-premises data store depending on how the Copy Activity is configured in the data pipeline.
trans-unit.target: The gateway copies data from the on-premises store to a cloud storage, or from a cloud storage to an on-premises data store depending on how the Copy Activity is configured in the data pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Note: For this step the gateway directly communicates with cloud based storage service (e.g. Azure Blob, Azure SQL etc) over secure (HTTPS) channel.
trans-unit.target: Note: For this step the gateway directly communicates with cloud based storage service (e.g. Azure Blob, Azure SQL etc) over secure (HTTPS) channel.

trans-unit.source: Ports and security considerations
trans-unit.target: Ports and security considerations

trans-unit.source: As mentioned above in the step by step walkthrough there are multiple ways of setting credentials for on-prem data stores with data factory.
trans-unit.target: As mentioned above in the step by step walkthrough there are multiple ways of setting credentials for on-prem data stores with data factory.

trans-unit.source: The port considerations vary for these options.
trans-unit.target: The port considerations vary for these options.

trans-unit.source: Using the Setting Credentials App: The Data Management Gateway installation program by default opens 8050 and 8051 ports on the local windows firewall for the gateway machine.
trans-unit.target: Using the Setting Credentials App: The Data Management Gateway installation program by default opens 8050 and 8051 ports on the local windows firewall for the gateway machine.

trans-unit.source: These ports are used by the Setting Credentials application to relay the credentials to the gateway.
trans-unit.target: These ports are used by the Setting Credentials application to relay the credentials to the gateway.

trans-unit.source: These ports are only opened for the machine on local windows firewall.
trans-unit.target: These ports are only opened for the machine on local windows firewall.

trans-unit.source: They cannot be reached from internet and you do not need have these opened in the corporate wide firewall.
trans-unit.target: They cannot be reached from internet and you do not need have these opened in the corporate wide firewall.

trans-unit.source: Using the <link><linkText>New-AzureDataFactoryEncryptValue</linkText><title></title></link> powershell commandlet: a.
trans-unit.target: Using the <link><linkText>New-AzureDataFactoryEncryptValue</linkText><title></title></link> powershell commandlet: a.

trans-unit.source: If you are using powershell command to encrypt the credentials and as a result you do not want gateway installation to open the inbound ports on gateway machine in windows firewall you can do that by using the following command during installation:
trans-unit.target: If you are using powershell command to encrypt the credentials and as a result you do not want gateway installation to open the inbound ports on gateway machine in windows firewall you can do that by using the following command during installation:

trans-unit.source: msiexec /q /i DataManagementGateway.msi NOFIREWALL=1
trans-unit.target: msiexec /q /i DataManagementGateway.msi NOFIREWALL=1

trans-unit.source: If you are using the Setting Credentials application you must launch it on a computer that is able to connect to the Data Management Gateway to be able to set credentials for the data source and to test connection to the data source.
trans-unit.target: If you are using the Setting Credentials application you must launch it on a computer that is able to connect to the Data Management Gateway to be able to set credentials for the data source and to test connection to the data source.

trans-unit.source: When copying data from/to an on-premises SQL Server database to/from an Azure SQL database, ensure the following:
trans-unit.target: When copying data from/to an on-premises SQL Server database to/from an Azure SQL database, ensure the following:

trans-unit.source: Firewall on the gateway machine allows outgoing TCP communication on TCP port 1433.
trans-unit.target: Firewall on the gateway machine allows outgoing TCP communication on TCP port 1433.

trans-unit.source: Configure Azure SQL firewall settings to add the IP address of the gateway machine to the allowed IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: Configure Azure SQL firewall settings to add the IP address of the gateway machine to the allowed IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: When copying data to/from on-premises SQL Server to any destination and the gateway and SQL Server machines are different, do the following: <link><linkText>configure Windows Firewall</linkText><title></title></link> on the SQL Server machine so that the gateway can access the database via ports that the SQL Server instance listens on.
trans-unit.target: When copying data to/from on-premises SQL Server to any destination and the gateway and SQL Server machines are different, do the following: <link><linkText>configure Windows Firewall</linkText><title></title></link> on the SQL Server machine so that the gateway can access the database via ports that the SQL Server instance listens on.

trans-unit.source: For the default instance, it is port 1433.
trans-unit.target: For the default instance, it is port 1433.

trans-unit.target: Send Feedback

trans-unit.target: We would really appreciate your feedback on this article.
